title: Git Workflow
description: Git is a version control system that tracks changes to your code. It allows you to collaborate, experiment safely, and maintain a clean history of your project. Understanding Git is essential for working on real development teams.

content.text: Git helps developers manage changes, avoid losing work, and collaborate effectively. It's used in almost every modern software project.

items: Tracks every change to your code
Provides a history of what changed and why
Integrates with GitHub, GitLab, and Bitbucket

content.text: Before learning commands, it's important to understand the basic ideas behind Git.
Repository (repo)
A project tracked by Git.
Commit
A snapshot of your code at a moment in time.
Branch
A separate line of development used for features or fixes.
Merge
Combining changes from one branch into another.
Remote
A version of your repo stored online (e.g., GitHub).
These commands form the foundation of everyday Git usage.

git init            # Start a new repository
git clone URL        # Download a repo
git status           # Check changes
git add .            # Stage all changes
git commit -m "msg"  # Save a snapshot
git push             # Upload changes
git pull             # Download latest changes
Branches allow you to work on features without affecting the main codebase.

git branch feature/login   # Create a branch
git checkout feature/login  # Switch to it
git switch feature/login    # (newer alternative)
git merge feature/login     # Merge into current branch
Branching is the safest way to experiment and collaborate.
A pull request (PR) is a request to merge your branch into the main project. It's where code review and collaboration happen.

items: Use branches for every feature or fix
Pull before you push to avoid conflicts
